author: UK Sport
title: Mikel Arteta bemoans Arsenal‚Äôs display in both boxes after home loss to West Ham
text:
Mikel Arteta bemoans Arsenal‚Äôs display in both boxes after home loss to West Ham
The Gunners missed the chance to return to the top of the Premier League on Thursday night.
Mikel Arteta admitted his side came up short in both boxes as Arsenal slumped to defeat to West Ham to miss out on regaining top spot in the Premier League.
The Gunners remain behind Liverpool as they lost 2-0 at the Emirates Stadium on what Arteta conceded was one of the most frustrating nights of his four-year tenure as Arsenal boss.
Tomas Soucek‚Äôs opener ‚Äì awarded after the VAR could not determine whether the whole ball had gone out of play in the build up ‚Äì and a second-half header from former Arsenal defender Konstantinos Mavropanos earned the visitors a deserved win.
Things could have been even better had Said Benrahma not had a stoppage-time penalty saved by David Raya on a night where Arteta applauded the performances of the opposition.
‚ÄúI congratulate West Ham and praise my players. That‚Äôs what I can tell you,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúThis is football. When you look at how much we generated in the game, to see the result is very disappointing. But they were better than us in both boxes. They had two shots, with the penalty three. We had 30.
Asked if it was among the most frustrating nights of his managerial career, Arteta replied: ‚ÄúIt is. But it‚Äôs football. Normally when the team generates so much it‚Äôs going to win games.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the way we‚Äôve done it. Against Brighton, we generated so much and against Liverpool as well, but we score goals in different ways.
‚ÄúWe have to make another step in that area to win games more comfortably, that‚Äôs for sure, because today the team deserves to win the game. There‚Äôs no question about that.‚Äù
Arteta successfully fought a Football Association charge after he criticised the officiating and VAR in defeat at Newcastle last month and was less vocal this time.
He did, however, suggest technology needs to be further advanced to make close calls, adding: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre saying it‚Äôs not conclusive. It‚Äôs a shame that with the technology that we have, that it‚Äôs not that clear so that we can say whether it‚Äôs out or in. It‚Äôs done. It‚Äôs gone. There‚Äôs nothing we can do about it now.
For West Ham and manager David Moyes, this was a rare taste of victory at the Emirates Stadium ‚Äì Moyes had failed to secure victory in his previous 72 Premier League away games at Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool or Manchester United.
West Ham were 17th at the turn of the year but went on to win the Europa Conference League and now sit just four points off the top four after this hard-fought and deserved win.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting ready to talk,‚Äù he told Amazon Prime.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think any of us are jumping to get it done too quickly, I think we are just happy to make sure we get it done. We will do, I don‚Äôt see any problems with that at all.
‚ÄúWe are not one of the top teams. We are trying to get up and grow the team. For West Ham to be in Europe is a great period.‚Äù

author: SAPO
title: Os 10% mais ricos do mundo causaram dois ter√ßos do aquecimento global, diz estudo - Atualidade - SAPO.pt - √öltima hora e not√≠cias de hoje atualizadas ao minuto
text:
SIC Not√≠cias 8 mai 2025 00:56 Atualidade Destaques SIC Not√≠cias Ver mais not√≠cias Os 10% mais ricos do mundo causaram dois ter√ßos do aquecimento global, diz estudo Estudo mostra a rela√ß√£o entre a desigualdade de emiss√µes baseada no rendimento e a injusti√ßa clim√°tica.
Olena Malik/Getty Images Os 10% mais ricos da popula√ß√£o mundial s√£o respons√°veis por dois ter√ßos do aquecimento global desde 1990 e pelo aumento de eventos clim√°ticos extremos, como ondas de calor e secas, derivados da crise clim√°tica, segundo um estudo.
A investiga√ß√£o, publicada na revista Nature Climate Change e citado na quarta-feira pela ag√™ncia Efe , avaliou at√© que ponto os diferentes grupos e sociedades contribuem para as emiss√µes e revelou que o 1% mais rico do mundo contribuiu 26 vezes mais do que a m√©dia global para o aumento dos extremos de temperatura global e 17 vezes mais para as secas na Amaz√≥nia.
O trabalho, conduzido pela ETH Zurich (Su√≠√ßa), mostra a rela√ß√£o entre a desigualdade de emiss√µes baseada no rendimento e a injusti√ßa clim√°tica, revelando que o consumo e os investimentos dos ricos tiveram e continuam a ter um impacto desproporcional nos eventos clim√°ticos extremos.
Estes efeitos s√£o "especialmente graves em regi√µes tropicais vulner√°veis, como a Amaz√≥nia, o Sudeste Asi√°tico e o Sul de √Åfrica" , que historicamente t√™m contribu√≠do menos para as emiss√µes globais.
O estudo mostra que os impactos clim√°ticos extremos n√£o s√£o apenas o resultado de emiss√µes globais abstratas, mas "podem estar diretamente ligados a estilos de vida e escolhas de investimento, que por sua vez est√£o ligados √† riqueza", sublinhou Sarah Sch√∂ngart, investigadora da ETH Zurique e principal autora do estudo.
"Verific√°mos que os emissores ricos desempenham um papel significativo na condu√ß√£o dos extremos clim√°ticos", e isso "fornece um forte apoio √†s pol√≠ticas clim√°ticas que visam reduzir as suas emiss√µes", salientou Sch√∂ngart. "Corrigir este desequil√≠brio √© crucial" Utilizando um modelo que combinava dados econ√≥micos e simula√ß√µes clim√°ticas, os investigadores conseguiram rastrear as emiss√µes de diferentes grupos de rendimentos globais e avaliar a sua contribui√ß√£o para extremos clim√°ticos espec√≠ficos.
Assim, descobriram que as emiss√µes dos 10% mais ricos da popula√ß√£o dos Estados Unidos e da China, somente, multiplicaram as temperaturas extremas em regi√µes vulner√°veis em duas ou tr√™s vezes.
"Se todos tivessem emitido como os 50% mais pobres da popula√ß√£o global, o aquecimento global teria sido m√≠nimo desde 1990", garantiu Carl-Friedrich Schleussner, coautor do estudo e diretor do Grupo de Investiga√ß√£o de Impactos Clim√°ticos Integrados do IIASA. "Corrigir este desequil√≠brio √© crucial para uma a√ß√£o clim√°tica justa e eficaz", lembrou o investigador. O estudo tamb√©m destaca a import√¢ncia das emiss√µes ligadas a investimentos financeiros e afirma que focar-se nos fluxos financeiros e nas carteiras de indiv√≠duos com rendimentos elevados pode gerar benef√≠cios clim√°ticos substanciais.
Os autores acreditam que estas descobertas podem ajudar a lan√ßar instrumentos de pol√≠ticas progressistas dirigidas √†s elites sociais e real√ßam que fazer os poluidores ricos pagarem tamb√©m pode fornecer o apoio muito necess√°rio para a adapta√ß√£o e perdas e danos em pa√≠ses vulner√°veis.
Reequilibrar a responsabilidade pela a√ß√£o clim√°tica de acordo com o contributo real para as emiss√µes "√© essencial", n√£o s√≥ para conter o aquecimento global, "mas tamb√©m para alcan√ßar um mundo mais justo e resiliente" , concluem os autores.
Com Lusa

author: Conor Ryan
title: Play
text:
Red Sox reliever Liam Hendriks is ready to open his checkbook if the 2025 Red Sox end up winning a World Series this October.
The 36-year-old righty was candid when asked during NESN‚Äôs ‚ÄúUnobstructed Views‚Äù broadcast of the Bruins/Sabres game about what he plans to do if Boston wins another Fall Classic.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve already got permission from my wife. If we [win] it, I‚Äôm doing the Jake Peavy thing. I‚Äôm buying the damn duck boat,‚Äù Hendriks told former Bruins Patrice Bergeron, Tuukka Rask, and Andrew Raycroft during Monday‚Äôs broadcast. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it will fit in my parking spot in Beacon Hill, though.‚Äù
Liam Hendriks has already planned for the Sox winning it all ‚¨áÔ∏è
"If we do it, I'm doing the Jake Peavy thing, I'm buying the damn duck boat." ü§£ #NESNViews | ü§ù @CoorsBanquet pic.twitter.com/WkzLf3RX98
‚Äî NESN (@NESN) March 18, 2025 Peavy ‚Äî who won a World Series title as a veteran starter on Boston‚Äôs 2013 roster ‚Äî infamously shelled out $75,000 to purchase his own amphibious vehicle as a keepsake from Boston‚Äôs improbable championship run.
While Peavy acknowledged on MLB Network in January 2022 that the duck boat is now a ‚Äúcenterpiece‚Äù to a wiffle ball field in his hometown of Mobile, Alabama, the former Cy Young Award winner admitted that the initial reason why he purchased the vehicle was to accommodate his entire family ahead of Boston‚Äôs World Series parade.
Remember when @JakePeavy_22 bought the duck boat his family rode on during the @RedSox 2013 World Series parade?
He still has it and there's an epic backstory ü¶Ü pic.twitter.com/K6eRjNQ3At
‚Äî MLB Network (@MLBNetwork) January 21, 2022 ‚ÄúI had a bunch of kids already at the time, I had my wife‚Äôs brothers, and I got there that morning and ‚Ä¶ me and Jon Lester were there together and we had six tickets apiece,‚Äù Peavy said. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòLook, I can‚Äôt wave to my grandparents on the side of this four-hour ride. They‚Äôve got to get on the boat.'‚Äù
Hendriks, who is looking to earn a high-leverage spot in Boston‚Äôs bullpen while recovering from Tommy John surgery, could be a key reason why the Red Sox put themselves in the running for a deep playoff push this fall.
While Hendriks has had an up-and-down spring training so far, the three-time All-Star does have 116 career saves on his resume and could complement a Red Sox bullpen that also features Justin Slaten and Aroldis Chapman.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got some arms who could be pretty special,‚Äù Hendriks told Peter Abraham of The Boston Globe of Boston‚Äôs bullpen in February. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good group and I‚Äôm excited to be out there with guys like Aroldis and Justin. I think we‚Äôll be surprisingly good. We have good balance.‚Äù

author: VNExplorer
title: Israel is retiring its Patriot missile batteries. They could help a struggling Ukraine.
text:
US soldiers participate in Patriot missile training at Mount Eitam, Israel in 2018. Sgt. 1st Class Jason Epperson/US Army
Israel has never been impressed with the US-made Patriot air defense system. In 1991, it failed to intercept nearly all of the Iraqi Scud missiles fired at Israeli cities. Israel may not need the Patriots, but Ukraine is pleading for more. Israel has never been satisfied with its version of the Patriot air defense system that Ukraine views as essential to its survival.
This creates a bizarre split screen where Ukraine was all but pleading for more Patriot missiles to defend its cities and forces on Monday even as Israel began to shut down its older Patriot batteries, a move that came less than a month after it battled an unprecedented missile barrage from Iran.
Israel and Ukraine‚Äôs experience with the Patriots could not have been more different. Israel first used Patriots in combat in 1991 against approximately 40 Scud ballistic missiles that Iraq fired at its cities. While the bombardments did not kill large numbers of people, Israel was disappointed with the Patriot‚Äôs pitiful performance, with officials estimating it shot down only one or possibly even zero Scuds.
Israel wouldn‚Äôt use the Patriot in combat again until the 2010s when it shot down drones and a Su-24 bomber coming from Syria. By then, the Patriot had become a very different system. Its early failures, including against Iraqi Scuds, led to an extensive system upgrade and missiles with an active radar seeker that directly strike the target to destroy it with kinetic energy. These newer ‚Äúhit-to-kill‚Äù missiles, the PAC-3, are estimated to cost around $4 million each. Their less sophisticated PAC-2 predecessor, on the other hand, are proximity-fusing missiles that explode near incoming missiles to eliminate them.
Since receiving its Patriots, with both PAC-2 and PAC-3 interceptor missiles, in early 2023, Ukraine has successfully used them to shoot down Russia‚Äôs Kinzhal missile, which Russia touted as an unstoppable hypersonic weapon, and, early this year, moved at least one launcher near the front lines and shot down a dozen of Russia‚Äôs best fighter jets.
The Patriot is only part of Israel‚Äôs missile shield that‚Äôs been heavily tested by Iran and its proxies in the wake of Hamas‚Äô Oct. 7 terror attacks. Israel has other options that are cheaper or built inside its country.
‚ÄúIsrael has long been looking for a more advanced and more indigenous system to supplement or replace the Patriot, not only given its service history but also the supply chain that it requires,‚Äù Ryan Bohl, a senior Middle East and North Africa analyst at the risk intelligence company RANE, told Business Insider.
‚ÄúThat this comes not long after Iran‚Äôs barrage of missiles against Israel isn‚Äôt a huge surprise with that ongoing trend,‚Äù Bohl said. ‚ÄúI think Israel views the Patriot as out of date and too expensive to keep up with given the breakthroughs that were demonstrated during that barrage by newer systems.‚Äù
A Patriot air defense system test-fired during a training in Chania, Greece, on November 8, 2017. Anthony Sweeney/US Army
Federico Borsari, a defense expert at the Center for European Policy Analysis, also believes Israel‚Äôs development of more advanced anti-missile systems weighed heavily on its decision to retire the Patriot.
‚ÄúIsrael‚Äôs decision to retire its Patriot PAC-2 fire units is in line with the process of modernization and progressive enhancement of its air defense architecture with more advanced capabilities, in particular Iron Dome and David‚Äôs Sling,‚Äù Borsari told BI.
‚ÄúThe latter‚Äôs Stunner missile, in particular, has a longer engagement range against aerodynamic threats (up to 300 km according to publicly available specifications) compared to the 160 km of the PAC-2‚Äôs GEM-T missiles,‚Äù Borsari said. ‚ÄúThe two systems have a similar engagement range for ballistic threats, although David‚Äôs Slings maximum range capability is likely higher than the Patriot‚Äôs PAC-3 missiles.‚Äù
The CEPA analyst noted that David‚Äôs Sling truck-mounted ELM-2084 radar adds ‚Äúmaneuverability and rapid redeployment‚Äù advantages.
‚ÄúDavid‚Äôs Sling interceptors are also designed to counter saturation, multi-threat attacks like the recent one launched by Iran, thanks to their integration with the shorter-range Iron Dome,‚Äù Borsari said.
Bohl pointed out the David‚Äôs Sling is effective for intercepting ‚Äúlow-flying attacks and/or tracking enemy projectiles.‚Äù
He also noted that the Stunner missile is significantly cheaper and, therefore, more cost-effective than its Patriot counterpart.
Israel previously refused a US request for its vintage Hawk missiles, long in storage and out of service, for Ukraine.
Analysts believe that might not necessarily be the case with the Patriots.
‚ÄúI think it remains entirely possible that Israel countenances a potential transfer of these Patriots back to the United States and hence on to Ukraine from there,‚Äù Bohl said. ‚ÄúCertainly, from the Israeli perspective, they would consider this fair play, as Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine has helped to dry up the much-needed 155 mm ammunition that Israel itself has required.‚Äù
If the Patriots don‚Äôt ultimately end up in Ukraine, it‚Äôs not inconceivable they could be transferred to a regional country. Jordan requested the US deploy a Patriot missile on its soil in October and helped intercept the Iranian barrage on April 13.
‚ÄúTransferring these Patriots to other third-party countries like Jordan or even Gulf Arab allies like the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, or even Saudi Arabia, I think is also in the cards as the United States looks to bolster air defenses region-wide,‚Äù Bohl said.
Borsari argues it is crucial for the US and the European countries to acquire the Israeli PAC-2 batteries for Ukraine.
‚ÄúWhile not sufficient to cover the entire front, they would significantly enhance Ukraine‚Äôs air defense as Russia increases its terrorist attacks against Ukrainian cities,‚Äù Borsari said. ‚ÄúWhile Israel has so far resisted calls to provide Ukraine with military support, pressure from the US and others could allow for this transfer.‚Äù
‚ÄúHanding over to Jordan is also possible, although, given the circumstances, Western countries would and should prioritize Ukraine.‚Äù
If you enjoyed this story, be sure to follow Business Insider on Microsoft Start.

‚ÄúMy job is not to be politically correct; It is to witness, observe, analyze and document the beautiful chaos that surrounds us all, so that future generations can understand how we got to this moment in time.‚Äù - Victor-Hugo Vaca II
"I'm known as the 'Nostradamus of the Art World' because my paintings foreshadow events but It's not that I can see the future, it's that as an artist, I've met the people who forge our future." - Victor-Hugo Vaca II
Public Trust Plummets As Fake News Media Spreads Misinformation and Lies While Ignoring Prescient Eyewitness Observations from New York Born Hispanic-American Artist Who Lived Through The Chinese Coronavirus Pandemic Outbreak In China. Now, stuck in the former Soviet Union as a dissident American Refugee due to the Chinese Coronavirus shutting down all international flights and forced PCR Test lobotomies and deadly, experimental vaccines required to travel back to the homeland he served to protect as a United States Naval Academy Midshipman Officer, the Nostradamus of the Art World, Maverick Artist Victor-Hugo, shares modern art gonzo journalism with global citizens.
